citations.narrative:
* There are an estimated 25 dogs that have no official identification on them at time of inspection. Official identification
is needed to ensure that each animal s identity can be known with certainty which helps to facilitate the inspection
process. The applicant must ensure that all live dogs on the premise shall be identified by an official tag, or a distinctive
and legible tattoo marking that is acceptable to and approved by the Administrator. If the licensee uses microchips as
official identification, then a functioning microchip reader must be made available to the inspector at time of facility
inspection. In addition, a variance from the regional office to use microchips must be maintained on file by the licensee.

* Ten un-weaned puppies are being housed on square plastic flooring that will allow the feet and legs to fall through
the openings in the flooring. The feet and legs of two puppies were observed falling through the openings of the
enclosure flooring. The licensee had covered a portion of their enclosures with carpet squares. However, there is
nothing to prevent these young puppies from moving to the uncovered portion of the enclosure where their feet and legs
can fall through the openings in the flooring. The daily activity and mobility of the puppies are affected when there feet and
legs fall through the openings. The potential for injury exists when the feet and legs pass through the openings in the
flooring. All primary enclosures must have floors constructed in a manner that protects the puppy’s feet and legs from
injury and does not allow the puppies' feet or legs to pass through any openings. Primary enclosures must have floors
that are constructed in a manner that protects the puppy’s feet and legs from injury and do not allow the puppies feet and
legs to pass through any openings. The licensee must have floors that are constructed in a manner that protects the
puppy's feet and legs from injury.

* No recorded date for annual heartworm testing for 125 dogs had been completed. Annual heartworm testing is
important for the health of the animals. Heartworm testing is done to ensure that there are no active internal parasites.
The applicant must ensure that all dogs are receiving vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs
(including rabies, parvovirus, and distemper) and sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests (including fleas,
worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class A license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by April 16, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
End Section

narrative:
2.50(a)(1) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
*   There are an estimated 25 dogs that have no official identification on them at time of inspection.   Official identification 
is needed to ensure that each animal s identity can be known with certainty which helps to facilitate the inspection 
process. The applicant must ensure that all live dogs on the premise shall be identified by an official tag, or a distinctive 
and legible tattoo marking that is acceptable to and approved by the Administrator.   If the licensee uses microchips as 
official identification, then a functioning microchip reader must be made available to the inspector at time of facility 
inspection.  In addition, a variance from the regional office to use microchips must be maintained on file by the licensee. 
3.6(a)(2)(x) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
*       Ten un-weaned puppies are being housed on square plastic flooring that will allow the feet and legs to fall through 
the openings in the flooring.  The feet and legs of two puppies were observed falling through the openings of the 
enclosure flooring.  The licensee had covered a portion of their enclosures with carpet squares.   However, there is 
nothing to prevent these young puppies from moving to the uncovered portion of the enclosure where their feet and legs 
can fall through the openings in the flooring. The daily activity and mobility of the puppies are affected when there feet and 
legs fall through the openings. The potential for injury exists when the feet and legs pass through the openings in the 
flooring.  All primary enclosures must have floors constructed in a manner that protects the puppy’s feet and legs from

injury and does not allow the puppies' feet or legs to pass through any openings.  Primary enclosures must have floors 
that are constructed in a manner that protects the puppy’s feet and legs from injury and do not allow the puppies feet and 
legs to pass through any openings. The licensee must have floors that are constructed in a manner that protects the 
puppy's feet and legs from injury. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
*   No recorded date for annual  heartworm testing for 125 dogs had been completed. Annual heartworm testing is 
important for the health of the animals.  Heartworm testing is done to ensure that there are no active internal parasites.   
The applicant must ensure that all dogs are receiving vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs 
(including rabies, parvovirus, and distemper) and sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests (including fleas, 
worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class A license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by April 16, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
End Section
